headline.main: THE IRREPRESSIBLE CONFLICT.; History of Slavery as a Political Issue. THE ORIGIN AND AIM OF MODERN PARTIES. Speech of Hon. William H. Seward in the Senate of the United States.

docs.snippet: The New-Bedford Standard tells of a young lady, Miss James, residing at Fair Haven, Mass., who was so low with disease of the heart and lungs, that her life was despaired of. She heard that Rev. Joseph K. Bellows, of this City, a Second Advent...
docs.lead_paragraph: The New-Bedford Standard tells of a young lady, Miss James, residing at Fair Haven, Mass., who was so low with disease of the heart and lungs, that her life was despaired of. She heard that Rev. Joseph K. Bellows, of this City, a Second Advent minister, was in town, and became impressed with the idea that she would recover if he would pray with her.

docs.snippet: LECTURE BY MR. WH. CURTIS NOYES.--Mr. NOYES del vered his second lecture to the students of Columbia College Law School and a crowded audidience, upon "Criminal Jurisprudence in America before the Revolution," on Tuesday evening.
docs.lead_paragraph: LECTURE BY MR. WH. CURTIS NOYES.--Mr. NOYES del vered his second lecture to the students of Columbia College Law School and a crowded audidience, upon "Criminal Jurisprudence in America before the Revolution," on Tuesday evening.

headline.main: The Shoemakers Still Striking.; THE HEMMERS AND STITCHERS IN THE FIELD-- FEMININE SPIRIT AROUSED. ANOTHER FEMININE GATHERING. THE MOVEMENT ELSEWHERE.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the afternoon--nothing occurred in the morning at Lynn--a meeting was held on the Common, at which Mr. JAMES DILLON presided. Mr. JOHN R. PARROTT made a financial speech, stating that money was wanted to keep the strikers afloat, and that a Treasurer for each Ward had been appointed.
